answers.author: Dustin Anderson
answers.text:
One reason a community may choose to utilize a strategic plan is to protect what that community views to be its unique character and community assets. The Town of Greenwich utilizes a decennial Plan of Conservation and Development to help guide the direction the Town. This plan is the result of an exhaustive community outreach program. CIP requests, where applicable, are tied to specific implementation steps outlined in the plan. Departments report on progress implementation on a biennial basis. 
The Plan of Conservation and Development serves as an additional guidepost to the traditional measures while department heads draft their annual operational plans. Successful progress of these operational plans is tied to performance-based compensation. 
Plans are indeed labor intensive. Additionally, a proper strategic plan requires a considerable capital outlay. Establishing buy-in from departments may be challenging. 
A well constructed plan has the benefit of tying the day-to-day administrivia and minutiae to a larger context. It – at times – can provide meaning for the work an organization does and the services the jurisdiction provides.

answers.author: Marnie Green
answers.text:
Hi Jessica,
The City of Richland, WA has successfully implemented a strategic plan that guides their day to day efforts as well as employee performance management process.  Here's a link: http://www.ci.richland.wa.us/DocumentView.aspx?DID=1321
The process has indeed been time consuming and for some, all encompassing. It includes extensive citizen input and commitment from the governing body.  Still, it has led to a focused approach to delivering city services.  To me, it's hard to have a forward-moving organization without some kind of planning process.

answers.author: Jose Machicao
answers.text:
Hi Jessica,
I think the strategic plan could be useful or useless, but depends on:
a) How the plan defines planned "achievements" and not just "actions". If the plan is addressing only actios or activities, it will always be useless.
b) How aligned is the plan to the City Vision
c) How is linked to a monitoring dashboard. If the plan is not monitored, cannot be useful.

answers.author: Kenneth Decker
answers.text:
Most plans--strategic or otherwise--end up as "door stops."  I concur with Jose, plans must be monitored.  I would go one step further... elected bodies must be committed to implementing the plans over the long term.  This is a problem because elected officials sweep into office with a sense of "mandate" from the people... and they generally feel that their political mandate supercedes any strategic plan crafted by a previous administration.  Strategic planning works better in the private sector where shifts in governance are not so frequent (or dramatic).  If the academics favoring strategic planning want to do something useful, they could start by convincing elected officials that planning should trump politics.

author: Jessica Schmale
text:
As a second-year graduate student in an MPA program, I am focusing my final professional paper on strategic planning in local governments (I am referring to planning in general, not just zoning and land use).  Stats show that over half of medium-large cities do not engage in integrated, comprehensive, long-term planning; this goes against much of the academic literature on the value of strategic planning.  I am curious: why should (or should not) municipalities use this planning model?  Several administrators I have spoken with cite time, resources, and rapidly changing environments as the main reason they don't use it.  Thoughts?  
Thank you!
title: Strategic Planning: Invaluable or a Waste of Time?
